entry.et: Middle English, from Old English pund, from Latin pondo pound, from abl. of pondus weight pendant

def.dt: :any of various units of mass and weight
:a unit now in general use among English-speaking peoples equal to 16 avoirdupois ounces or 7000 grains or 0.4536 kilogram see weight table
:the basic monetary unit of the United Kingdom called also pound sterling
:any of numerous basic monetary units of other countries see money table
:the basic monetary unit of Ireland from 1921 to 2001
:lira
:the basic monetary unit of Cyprus from 1960 to 2008

entry.et: Middle English, enclosure, from Old English pund-

def.dt: :an enclosure for animals
:a public enclosure for stray or unlicensed animals a dog pound
:a depot for holding impounded personal property until redeemed by the owner a car pound
:a place or condition of confinement
:an enclosure within which fish are kept or caught
:the inner compartment of a fish trap or pound net

entry.et: alteration of Middle English pounen, from Old English pūnian

def.dt: :to reduce to powder or pulp by beating
:to strike heavily or repeatedly
:to produce with or as if with repeated vigorous strokes usually used with out pound out a story on the typewriter
:to inculcate by insistent repetition :drive day after day the facts were pounded home to them Ivy B. Priest
:to move, throw, or carry forcefully and aggressively pound the ball down the field
:to move along heavily or persistently pounded the pavement looking for work
:to drink or consume rapidly :slug pound down some beers
:to strike heavy repeated blows
:pulsate throb my heart was pounding
:to move with or make a heavy repetitive sound
:to work hard and continuously usually used with away
:an act or sound of pounding
Ezra Loomis 1885–1972 Am. poet
Roscoe 1870–1964 Am. jurist

entry.et: from the original recipe prescribing a pound of each of the principal ingredients

def.dt: :a rich butter cake made with a large proportion of eggs and shortening

entry.et: from the phrase penny-wise and pound-foolish

def.dt: :imprudent in dealing with large sums or large matters
:the transport of one pound of mail or express for one mile
:a fish trap consisting of a netting arranged into a directing wing and an enclosure with a narrow entrance
